resources.string: \t\tInitially created as a way to test the Advanced-Adapters library, this app now serves as a demonstration of all available adapters and their associating features found within it. The Advanced-Adapters library spawned out of frustration in having to constantly re-write a new adapter for various apps I\'ve worked on over the years. Needing a custom solution proved far more common then needing the generic ArrayAdapter provided by Android. While their version serves a basic generic purpose, it\'s filtering inconsistencies/bugs became a pain to deal with, ultimately requiring me to re-write their adapter any time I wanted to support filtering.

The following is a demonstration of Android's ArrayAdapter in action to show just how easy it is to break. Mostly the problems revolve around the filter. Try doing this:
 
 	 - Perform a search
 	 - Close the search view
 	 - Attempt to add a new movie
 	 - Beholdâ€¦nothing is added.
 	 - Demo is now in a bad state.
 	 - Hit back and re-enter demo.
 	 - You're back in a good state.
 
 As soon as the ArrayAdapter performs one search, the adapter can longer be mutated without seeing problems. Can you find any other problems? Head on over to the wiki to find out more issues.

This is a demonstration of the ArrayBaseAdapter, which is an adapter backed by an ArrayList. This adapter is an improved version of Android\'s ArrayAdapter, resolving many of it\'s issues. Most notably, all the filtering problems.\n \n If filtering is not required, it\'s strongly recommended to use the SimpleArrayBaseAdapter instead.
\t\tThough heavily modified, Android\'s ArrayAdapter served as the foundational code for the Advanced-Adapters library.

This is a demonstration of the SimpleArrayBaseAdapter class, which is an adapter backed by an ArrayList. This adapter is an improved version of Android\'s ArrayAdapter but removes filtering support. As a result, there is no need for synchronized blocks which may help those worried about performance.\n \n If filtering is required, it\'s strongly recommended to use the ArrayBaseAdapter instead.

This is a demonstration of the SimpleSparseArrayBaseAdapter which, as the name suggests, is an adapter backed by a SparseArray. It exposes most of the SparseArray methods with the key mapping to an adapter\'s row id and vice versa. Keep in mind this behaves like a map, not a list. Putting to the adapter is not the same as adding to the adapter.\n \n This adapter does not support filtering and as a result contains no synchronized blocks which may help those worried about performance. If filtering is required, it\'s strongly recommended to use the SparseArrayBaseAdapter instead.

This is a demonstration of the SparseArrayBaseAdapter which, as the name suggests, is an adapter backed by a SparseArray. It exposes most of the SparseArray methods with the key mapping to an adapter\'s row id and vice versa. Keep in mind this behaves like a map, not a list. Putting to the adapter is not the same as adding to the adapter.\n \n This adapter supports filtering. If filtering is not required, it\'s strongly recommended to use the SimpleSparseArrayBaseAdapter instead.
